page_analysis.text_content:
Balconies, decks, & outdoor areas on upper floors

Outdoor areas on upper levels that are roofed DO count toward gross floor area regardless of the design
(including whether or not the sides are open).

An outdoor area on an upper floor is considered to be
roofed if the eave over that area is deeper than the eave
over the rest of the building. This may be illustrated by
comparing Roof Plans 1 & 2 of Fig 10.

Fig 10 Balconies

Roof plan 1
Roof plan 2

Note: Pop-out balconies are
subject to the same evaluation.

Roof Plan 1
Area A: Counts because it is roofed
Area B: Does not count because this arbor is substantially open
Area C: Does not count because the overhang is the same size as the over-
hang around the rest of the house and is considered to be open

Width of overhang
over the balcony

Width of overhang around
the rest of the house

C
B
A

Roof Plan 2
Area A: Counts because it is roofed
Area B: Counts because the overhang here is greater than the overhang
around the rest of the house, and considered to be roofed
Area C: Does not count because it is open

Width of overhang
over the balcony

Width of overhang around
the rest of the house

B
C
A

visual_elements.description: An isometric view of a building section showing two upper-level outdoor areas. The upper area (Roof plan 1) has a partial roof structure (pergola-like) and a solid roof section. The lower area (Roof plan 2) is an open balcony. Arrows point from 'Roof plan 1' and 'Roof plan 2' labels to their respective areas on the building.

A top-down 'Roof Plan 1' diagram illustrating an outdoor area divided into three sections: A, B, and C. Area A is hatched with diagonal lines, Area B is hatched with a grid pattern, and Area C is solid white. There are labels for 'Width of overhang over the balcony' and 'Width of overhang around the rest of the house' with double-headed arrows indicating these dimensions. A dashed line indicates the extent of the overhang.

A top-down 'Roof Plan 2' diagram illustrating an outdoor area divided into three sections: A, B, and C. Area A is hatched with diagonal lines, Area B is hatched with a grid pattern, and Area C is solid white. There are labels for 'Width of overhang over the balcony' and 'Width of overhang around the rest of the house' with double-headed arrows indicating these dimensions. A solid line indicates the extent of the overhang.

structural_elements.main_heading: Balconies, decks, & outdoor areas on upper floors
sections: Outdoor areas on upper levels that are roofed DO count toward gross floor area regardless of the design (including whether or not the sides are open).

An outdoor area on an upper floor is considered to be roofed if the eave over that area is deeper than the eave over the rest of the building. This may be illustrated by comparing Roof Plans 1 & 2 of Fig 10.
Area A: Counts because it is roofed
Area B: Does not count because this arbor is substantially open
Area C: Does not count because the overhang is the same size as the over-hang around the rest of the house and is considered to be open
Area A: Counts because it is roofed
Area B: Counts because the overhang here is greater than the overhang around the rest of the house, and considered to be roofed
Area C: Does not count because it is open
Note: Pop-out balconies are subject to the same evaluation.
